AuditBot - Quantitative and Qualitative Research

My team investigated user attitudes about reporting algorithmic bias in the User-Centered Research and Evaluation course at Carnegie Mellon University. Our exploratory and generative research culminated in the design of a chat-based approach to auditing social media in the form of AuditBot, for Instagram.

Part of a user flow diagram (Click to see the rest)

  • time range: October-December 2021
  • stakeholders: social media users, AI researchers, social media companies
  • methods: Stakeholder and Empathy Mapping, Semi-Structured Interviews, Think-Aloud Testing, Contextual Inquiry, Affinity Diagramming, Storyboarding, Speed Dating
  • tools: Figma, Miro
  • my role: Project Manager, User Researcher, Designer
  • team members: John Jongyeon Chae, Priya Jain, Lisa Leung, Yumi Sato

Our research uncovered that everyday users have a difficult time recognizing algorithmic bias. We found that users lack motivation to report incidences of algorithmic bias due to feeling that their voice is inconsequential to companies that host social media platforms. With our design solution, we aim to leverage simplicity, transparency, and anonymized social proof in the content-reporting experience.
My storyboards for sending and receiving shift swap requests (Click for full view)
Scroll through our poster on Figma!

Overall, this course has greatly informed the way I now approach user experience design prompts. It also allowed me to flex my drawing and documentation skills, and gave me exposure to the wonders of the Figma prototyping software. Thanks to Professor Jacob and to the excellent homework group #17 for being great learning partners!
